facts.text: Appellant convicted by Additional Sessions Judge, Jodhpur under s. 314 read with s. 109, Indian Penal Code, affirmed by Rajasthan High Court on March 15, 1967.
Charge: Appellant abetted Mst. Radha at Jodhpur to cause miscarriage of Miss Atoshi Dass alias Amola some days prior to May 1, 1963.
Miss Atoshi Dass died on May 1, 1963 due to septicemia from administration of tablets and introduction of laminaria dento by Mst. Radha.
Appellant was resident of Gramotthan Pratishthan at Jalore in 1962-63.
Miss Atoshi Dass was young, unmarried teacher at Indra Bal Mandir, Tikhi, under appellant's management.
Illicit relationship developed between appellant and Miss Atoshi Dass, resulting in her pregnancy.
Appellant took Miss Dass to Jodhpur to cause abortion through Mst. Radha.
Appellant denies illicit relation with Miss Atoshi Dass and abetting abortion; denies death due to abortion attempt.
Mst. Radha tried with appellant but acquitted for lack of evidence.
Death of Miss Dass due to septicemia from laminaria dento, per Dr. A.J. Abraham PW 4.
Evidence of illicit intimacy: PW 6 Chhayadass (sister), corroborated by PW 7 M.B. Sen and PW Misri Lal.
Miss Chhayadass unreliable: gave false evidence, tutored by police, deviated from commitment court statements.
Deceased had illicit relation with Sood at Delhi, per Exh. D-3 (self-addressed letter in her handwriting).
Appellant and deceased went to Jodhpur on April 24, 1963; she had work there; he left her with Senguptas.
Ex. P-4: Letter by deceased to appellant dated 28-4-63, mentions going to Mst. Radha for medicine, tablet causing pain, no mention of appellant instigating.
Appellant charged with abetting Mst. Radha but convicted of abetting deceased.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant abetted the causing of miscarriage leading to death of Miss Atoshi Dass.
Whether conviction valid despite mismatch between charge (abetting Mst. Radha) and conviction (abetting deceased).

petitioner_arguments.text: No illicit relation with deceased; no abetment of abortion; death not due to abortion attempt.
Charge mismatch prejudiced defense: defended against abetting Mst. Radha, not deceased.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 107 IPC; Willie Slaney v. State of MP; Faguna Kanta Nath v. State of Assam

petitioner_arguments.text: PW 6 Chhayadass unreliable, tutored by police.
Deceased had other paramour (Sood), reducing motive.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant had illicit relation, took deceased to Jodhpur for abortion via Mst. Radha; abetted miscarriage.

court_reasoning.text: Satisfactory evidence of illicit intimacy but not sole paramour (Sood via Exh D-3); intimacy and pregnancy alone insufficient for abetment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Illicit intimacy established but no evidence of abetment.

court_reasoning.text: Travel to Jodhpur not incriminating as she had work and he left her with others.
PW 6 Chhayadass unreliable: tutored, deviated from commitment court, no prior knowledge of abortion talks.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reliance on her evidence for abetment.

court_reasoning.text: Ex P-4 does not implicate appellant in instigating miscarriage.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Letter contents do not support prosecution.

court_reasoning.text: Charge mismatch caused prejudice: defended against abetting Radha, not deceased; falls within Faguna Kanta Nath rule.

holdings.text: No legal basis for conviction of abetting miscarriage.
Conviction invalid due to prejudicial charge error.

precedents_cited.relevance: Rule on admissibility under Evidence Act s.32(1)

precedents_cited.case_name: Willie (William) Slaney v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Absence of charge or error not fatal unless prejudice caused

precedents_cited.case_name: Faguna Kanta Nath v. State of Assam
Gallu Sah v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: High Court reliance; distinguishable as accused was member of unlawful assembly

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offence of abetting miscarriage; definition of abetment by instigation, conspiracy or aid

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Admissibility of dying declaration or statement

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; appellant acquitted of conviction under s.314 r/w s.109 IPC as no evidence of abetment and prejudicial charge error.

key_quotes.text: The fact that the appellant was on terms of illicit intimacy with the deceased, an unmarried girl and that she later became pregnant through him is without more, not sufficient to connect the appellant with the crime.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects inference of abetment from intimacy alone

key_quotes.text: No reliance can be placed on the evidence of such a witness [Chhayadass].
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: the contents of the said letter do not in any manner support the prosecution case that the appellant instigated the deceased to cause miscarriage.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Ex P-4 does not prove abetment
